Description: A pendant: of white flint, is pear-shaped and flat on both faces. It is fairly thick in relation to its length and has a groove running around its edge. The lower face is smooth; on the other is a large, round pit where part of the stone has come away naturally. The threading hole above the central pit may be natural.
Curator's comments: This object is presumably to be identified with the 'pierced flint' found with a cooking pot in group 1016 (G. Brunton, ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’, p.25). Bibliography: G. Brunton, ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’ (London, 1937), 25.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (59)
